The clinical implementation of NAC has facilitated breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) and sentinel lymph node biopsy for women who historically would require mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
2, 3 The optimal outcome after NAC is a pathologic complete response (pCR), which is defined as no remaining invasive or in situ cancer in the breast. A pCR is a surrogate end point that is a marker for improved disease-free and overall survival.
4, 6 The likelihood of achieving pCR is largely based on breast cancer subtype (clinically defined by immunohistochemical surrogates of estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, and ERBB2 (formerly HER2 or HER2/neu) amplification, with ERBB2-positive and triple-negative subtypes having the highest likelihood of pCR of up to 66.2%
7 and 37%,
8 respectively.
